lineage.Process: Merge CMM_all_2007srt;CBM_CO_Merge C:\CoalBedMethane\2006_Update_wells_outlines\ToMerge\CBM_all_2007.shp "field field true false false 30 Text 0 0 ,First,#,CMM_all_2007srt,field,-1,-1,CBM_CO_Merge,field,-1,-1;state state true false false 2 Text 0 0 ,First,#,CMM_all_2007srt,state,-1,-1,CBM_CO_Merge,state,-1,-1;basin basin true false false 20 Text 0 0 ,First,#,CMM_all_2007srt,basin,-1,-1,CBM_CO_Merge,basin,-1,-1;ET_ID ET_ID true false false 9 Long 0 9 ,First,#,CMM_all_2007srt,ET_ID,-1,-1"

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.2.1350

descript.abstract: This dataset is field boundary polygons of Coalbed Methane (CBM) based on producing wells in the USA. Field outline polygons were created by buffering wells from each field. Buffered well polygons from each field were then unioned into a single polygon record (may contain multiple rings). A smoothing algorithm was applied to the polygons.
descript.purpose: This dataset was developed in order to make a map showing the location of CBM fields in the US.
descript.supplinf:
This CBM field outline polygon layer was created to represent a very approximate area of CBM gas production from well point data. This was done as a portion of a project entitled "US Coalbed Methane" by the EIA.
Data source for the wells is digital well files from 17 state entities (oil & gas commissions or geological surveys) plus the USGS (for VA), and 2 private companies (Torrent Energy for OR, BPI for IL). Wells were edited to include only CBM producers and to verify/ standardize field names. Unnamed fields were given "wildcat" names based on their counties, e.g " WC LOGAN CO-1".
In most of the states where CBM production is well established, the well files are clear in differentiating drilled wells from permitted locations, and producing wells from dry tests. However, in states where commercial producdtion is not yet clearly established (e.g. IL or IN), the well files represent more assumed CBM activity rather than confirmed CBM production.
CBM wells were buffered with a radius, then well buffer polygons unioned together by the field name attribute. Buffer distance (radius) was chosed as a function of the standard well spacing unit size. The statesâ€™ minimum well spacing rules were used as starting point (e.g. NM: 320 acres/CBM well in San Juan Basin, 160 acres/CBM well in Raton Basin), with a maximum spacing unit size of 320 acres. Iteration was done in many cases to obtain more reasonable buffer connectivity for a field. For example, in areas where wells were drilled on spacing greater than the spacing rules, the buffer distance was increased by 1-2 steps of standard spacing (20, 40, 80, 160, or 320 acres per well). The corresponding buffer distances in feet for each standard spacing unit used were the same ones derived by the EIA and documented in appendix 6 of the report "Scientific Inventory of Onshore Federal Lands' Oil and Gas Resources and Reserves and the Extent and Nature of Restrictions or Impediments to their Development", January 2003 (see report at http://www.doi.gov/epca/).
An exception to the buffering process was used for the Arkansas portion of the Arkoma Basin, where a single operator (CDX) is using multilateral pinnate horizontal wells to develop the CBM. It was not possible to obtain BHL locations for each of the pinnate wells, so each quarter-section that contains a horizontal well is included in the field boundary. This results in a rectilinear outline rather than the smoothed curves of a buffered well field boundary.
No warranty, expressed or implied, is made by the author, by Z Inc. or by EIA regarding data accuracy, precision, currency or completeness; or concerning the results to be obtained from queries or use of the data. All data is expressly provided "AS IS" and "WITH FAULTS". The purpose of this dataset is to show the approximate location of coalbed methane fields. This layer is based on well data provided by individual organizations and state entities, which was not checked for accuracy or completeness. No responsibility is assumed for damages or other liabilities due to the accuracy, availability, use or misuse of the information herein provided. The GIS data is made available as a public service. GIS information is in the public domain and may be copied without permission; citation of the source is appreciated.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Coal-bearing stratgraphic unit of 2 or more formations

attr.attrdefs: State surveys and oil/gas regulatory bodies, literature sources

attr.attrdef: Names of coals completed for production
attr.attrdefs: State surveys and oil/gas regulatory bodies

dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Field boundaries are based on suface locations of wells from State oil and gas survey or oil & gas regulatory bodies. There is virtually no bottom hole location (BHL) information for horizontal CBM wells. Due to the multiple BHLs generated by CD's mulit-pinnate well design in AR, the field boundaries represent quarter-sections developed (square outlines).
